newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel, Jordan reach interim water accord.
newsitem.headline: Israel, Jordan reach interim water accord.

text.p: Israel and Jordan have resolved a two-week crisis over a deal to ease the kingdom's water shortage, National Infrastructure Minister Ariel Sharon said on Friday.
"We reached a conclusion yesterday at a meeting of experts," Sharon told Israel Radio. Ministry sources said the meeting took place in Amman.
"The programme itself speaks of 50 million cubic metres salty water within our borders being transferred to Jordanian territory and there treated and turned into first-class drinking water," he said.
The ministry sources said the sides agreed that until the desalination project was completed, Israel would give Jordan some of its own water, possibly from the Galilee or underground sources.
Negotiating teams will meet again next week to work out the details, the sources said.
Under a 1994 peace treaty, Israel agreed to provide Jordan with 50 million cubic metres (1.75 billion cubic feet) of water annually within a year of the treaty's taking effect.
The two countries disagreed on how to implement the accord, and Jordan accused Israel of trying to back out of the deal at the last minute.

The dispute reached a crisis two weeks ago when Jordanian Crown Prince Hassan cancelled a meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. The interim agreement follows a secret meeting between Jordan's King Hussein and Netanyahu at the Jordanian Red Sea port of Aqaba.
